discussion.content:
INDEPENDENT VMs
=================
Latest - Low RPO (may not app-consistent)
Latest Processed - Low RTO
Latest app-consistent - app-consistent, 

DEPENDENT VMs
===============
Latest multi-VM processed - same as Latest Processed 
Latest multi-VM app-consistent - same as Latest app-consistent

comments.content: D is ok

Latest processed:::: Use this option to fail over VMs to the latest recovery point already processed by Site Recovery. You can see the latest processed recovery point in the VM Latest Recovery Points. This option provides a low RTO as no time is spent to processing the unprocessed data

discussion.content:
Requirements:

- Each server workload is independent of the other
- Workloads are stateless 
- Failover as quickly as possible 

A. Latest

> Provides the lowest RPO

B. Latest app-consistent 

> There are no hints, that app-consistent recovery points have been enabled. So I guess it can be ruled out. 

C. Latest multi-VM processed 

> The requirements say "workloads are independent of each other". Also there is no hint that multi-VM consistency got enabled. I guess this can be ruled out 

D. Latest processed 

> Provdes a low RTO because no time is spent processing unprocessed data

Conclusion: 

> As the workloads are stateless, there is no need to waste time on recovering the exact state of the VM. So answer D) is sufficient and should be even faster than A)

comments.content:
A (Latest) has the lowest RPO (as you mentioned), but also would not be processing any data either because the app is stateless.

Seems like the correct answer is "A."

Self correcting a bit....

Looking further, it might be trying to trip you up. I could read that as multiple VMs in which case the correct answer would be "Latest multi-VM Processed".

If it's a single VM, then the answer would be "Latest Processed"

It would not be "Latest" as i initially thought because, Site Recovery will first create a recovery point and then do the fail over. Because these are stateless, there is no need.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/site-recovery/site-recovery-test-failover-to-azure

the right answer is "latest processed" please read the link below:

"Please note that when the source region goes down, there is no more log processing possible. So, you will have to failover to Latest Processed recovery point. See the next point to understand more."

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/site-recovery/site-recovery-failover#run-a-failover

discussion.content:
RTO is how quickly the applications will be online in the secondary site, and RPO is how much data loss would occur in the event of a failover.

So based on the requirement, Latest Processed is correct as it has low RTO.
D. Latest processed
D is correct answer.

Even though I would lean towards D ie latest processed owing to "Statelessness and lowest RTO (ie the workloads are available in Azure as quickly as possible)".
 For D to work, following assumption has to be made for which there is no clarity in the question:
There had not been any updates (apps, OS, data, other binaries) to the VM after the "latest processed".

STATELESS and FASTEST are the major key here.
I think the correct answer is A.
The correct answer is D.

Answer is correct:
Note that as per this link:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/site-recovery/site-recovery-failover
Please note that when the source region goes down, there is no more log processing possible. So, you will have to failover to Latest Processed recovery point. See the next point to understand more.
And this is exactly the scenario mention here
Latest provides the lowest RPO, but since the question said fastest time, then Latest Processed would be best, as it has the lowest RTO which is Recovery Time Objective.
Given answer is correct. TRO= how quickly you want your data back? RTO= how much data you afford loosing.

Answer D is correct, The question is really asking for shorted RTO, which is provided by option D.
Latest processed: Use this option to fail over VMs to the latest recovery point already processed by Site Recovery. You can see the latest processed recovery point in the VM Latest Recovery Points. This option provides a low RTO as no time is spent to processing the unprocessed data

questions.question_text:
You plan to use Azure Site Recovery to protect several on-premises physical server workloads. Each server workload is independent of the other. The workloads are stateless.
You need to recommend a failover strategy to ensure that if the on-premises data center fails, the workloads are available in Azure as quickly as possible.
Which failover strategy should you include in the recommendation?

DRAG DROP -
Your company identifies the following business continuity and disaster recovery objectives for virtual machines that host sales, finance, and reporting applications in the company's on-premises data center:
✑ The finance application requires that data be retained for seven years. In the event of a disaster, the application must be able to run from Azure. The recovery time objective (RTO) is 10 minutes.
✑ The reporting application must be able to recover point-in-time data at a daily granularity. The RTO is eight hours.
✑ The sales application must be able to fail over to a second on-premises data center.
You need to recommend which Azure services meet the business continuity and disaster recovery objectives. The solution must minimize costs.
What should you recommend for each application? To answer, drag the appropriate services to the correct applications. Each service may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

comments.content:
Is it possible to use ASR to fail over from on-premise to another data center on-premise??
Only then answer for Sales would be ASR .

It was one of its features. According to these urls, this feature has been deprecated: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/site-recovery/site-to-site-deprecation and https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/site-recovery/vmware-physical-secondary-disaster-recovery#end-of-support-announcement.
The only way to fail over between on prem datacenters would be indirectly: first fail over from primary on-prem datacenter to azure recovery site and then fail backup from azure to secondary on-prem datacenter (failing back to an alternate vCenter as described in point 9 in https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/site-recovery/vmware-azure-reprotect).
Probably too much complicated and as there is no RTO for sales, Azure backup only would be enough to recreate the environment in secondary datacenter.
I don't really know what my answer would be if this question appears to me
Yes, it's one of it's fetaures, to orchestrate replication and failover between on-premises datacenter with no direct connection between them, i.e. over internet.

Totally agree:
1) SR only: requirement for app to run with RTO 10 min, no backup requirement
2) Finances: retain data for 7 years - backup, fail-over requirement - SR
3) Reporting: no failover requirement - no SR, daily granularity, RTO 8 hours - fits backup,
You are correct.
I have an impression Backup RTO would be more than 8 hours but not sure. Any link against it please?

So the correct answer is,
Sales - ASR (Only failover requirement)
Finance - Backup + Manual replication (ASR - Not guranteed RPO of 10 minutes, only 2 hours in guranteed)
Reporting - ASR (Set RPO to 24 hours, RTO for ASR is guranteed not more than 2 hours)
Site Recovery - RTO is upto 120 minutes, here it is 10 minutes, which may not be possible with ASR for Finance

Azure Site Recovery cannot failover to the second On-premises datacenter. It can only do failover and failback to the original on-premise datacenter.

Looks wrong ... site recovery manager is for general replication and moving data between separate geographical locations. Microsoft position backup for fine-grained data recovery. E.g. Finance here needs site recover mgr. + backup

choices.C: Deploy a load balancer and a virtual machine scale set across two availability zones.
choices.B: In two Azure regions, deploy a load balancer and a virtual machine scale set.
choices.A: In two Azure regions, deploy a Traffic Manager profile and a web app.
choices.D: In two Azure regions, deploy a load balancer and a web app.

questions.question_text:
You plan to move a web application named App1 from an on-premises data center to Azure.
App1 depends on a custom COM component that is installed on the host server.
You need to recommend a solution to host App1 in Azure. The solution must meet the following requirements:
✑ App1 must be available to users if an Azure data center becomes unavailable.
✑ Costs must be minimized.
What should you include in the recommendation?

comments.content: True...
C is ok
can load balancer work across regions? Answer is no. So A is correct. Sometimes cost saving can't acheive
nope, load balancer does not work across regions

The requirement does not need region availabilty. The requirement is: ...App1 must be available to users if an Azure data center becomes unavailable... 
Option C with two datacenters is enough. I choose: C.

What about the COM component that runs on a SERVER and App depends on, so are you going to install two instances of it for two regional Apps?. LB with Scaleset fulfills the requirement. IMHO C is correct.
No need to go across region. Availability set with in region will work.

Availability Zone: Unique physical locations *within* a region.
C is the correct answer as the machine needs a custom COM component, which a web app is unable to accommodate. (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/azure/migration/app-service#com-and-com-components)

discussion.content: Question is asking about data center failure and minimize costs. Thsi will be satisfied with Loadbalancer, scale set with availability zones.

thank you, web app cannot support COM component

C. Deploy a load balancer and a virtual machine scale set across two availability zones.
C is correct answer.
app service doesn't work with com components as far as I know. So you should look for a VM based or container solution. C looks tight

Correct answer : C
Load Balancer (Traffic manager not required...) 
Virtual Machine Scale Sets (coz of COM component on the host server needs to be installed...)
Availability Zones (to avoid data center failure...)

For me the answer is C

Azure App Service does not allow the registration of COM components on the platform. If your app makes use of any COM components, these need to be rewritten in managed code and deployed with the site or application.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/azure/migration/app-service
C is the correct answer

A is Correct.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/azure/migration/app-service
"Azure App Service with Windows Containers
If your app cannot be migrated directly to App Service, consider App Service using Windows Containers, which enables usage of the GAC, COM components, MSIs, full access to .NET FX APIs, DirectX, and more."

A. In two Azure regions, deploy a Traffic Manager profile and a web app.

> Can be ruled out, as Azure App Service doesn't support COM components

B. In two Azure regions, deploy a load balancer and a virtual machine scale set.

> As we are not having two independent web applications and we don't have any further details about the architecture of App1 this can be ruled out as well. 

C. Deploy a load balancer and a virtual machine scale set across two availability zones.

> The scaling would allow to reduce cost for situations of lighter traffic. And the use of avail. zones fulfills the requirement of high availability. 

D. In two Azure regions, deploy a load balancer and a web app.

> Can be ruled out. See comment for A.

Conclusion: > C. should be the correct answer. 

Refs: 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/azure/migration/app-service

C is definitely the correct answer. There is no mention of needing multiple regions. Availability zones protect from datacenter failures (which is what the requirement is). Using VMs to register COM. Using scale sets to scale in previously mentioned VMs to minimize cost.
Answer is C "minimize costs" -> don't use resources across regions

it has to be C.
 "Azure App Service does not allow the registration of COM components on the platform."

1) In azure zone if one DataCenter fails others has replication already which will not affect to the App. As we know In Azure Zone all data replicates between Zones Datacenters. 
2) As load balancer acts in one region and can't be operate between regions we can exclude LoadBalancer in two region answers 
3) Traffic Manager acts as a Web traffic Load balancer across regions and it router to most appropriate service endpoint. 
Also for the pricing.Traffic Manager price is 0.54 $ per million queries but Load balancer price is 0.025 $ per hour also 0.005$ per GB data processing. In this situation Traffic Manager is most reliable answer that Load balancer. 
So for me answer is A. Traffic Manager

comments.content:
Almost true. You can have Load Balancer across regions, using Standard SKU with Standard Public IP. But it is not the case, since the questions asks for a single Data Center failure and reducing costs. In this case, 1 Load Balance and Availability Set will be cheaper then duplicate the infrastructure in 2 different regions, as option A states - In two Azure regions, deploy a Traffic Manager profile and a web app.
So, the right answer is C, considering the requirements (Costs and just 1 Data CEnter failure) and the COM component, that should run in VMs, not in webapps

questions.answer_description:
If your storage account has GRS enabled, then your data is durable even in the case of a complete regional outage or a disaster in which the primary region isn't recoverable.
Note: The recovery time objective (RTO) is the targeted duration of time and a service level within which a business process must be restored after a disaster (or disruption) in order to avoid unacceptable consequences associated with a break in business continuity.
Incorrect Answers:
B: Azure Site Recovery would not protect against an Azure region failure.
Azure Site Recovery guarantees a two-hour Recovery Time Objective.
References:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/common/storage-redundancy-grs https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/support/legal/sla/site-recovery/v1_0/
questions.question_text:
You plan to deploy a payroll system to Azure. The payroll system will use Azure virtual machines that run SUSE Linux Enterprise Server and Windows.
You need to recommend a business continuity solution for the payroll system. The solution must meet the following requirements:
✑ Minimize costs.
✑ Provide business continuity if an Azure region fails.
✑ Provide a recovery time objective (RTO) of 120 minutes.
✑ Provide a recovery point objective (RPO) of five minutes.
What should you include in the recommendation?

choices.C: unmanaged disks that use geo-redundant storage (GRS)
choices.A: Microsoft System Center Data Protection Manager (DPM)

Simple to deploy and manage
Set up Azure Site Recovery simply by replicating an Azure VM to a different Azure region directly from the Azure portal. As a fully integrated offering, Site Recovery is automatically updated with new Azure features as they’re released. Minimize recovery issues by sequencing the order of multi-tier applications running on multiple virtual machines. Ensure compliance by testing your disaster recovery plan without impacting production workloads or end users. And keep applications available during outages with automatic recovery from on-premises to Azure or Azure to another Azure region.

https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/services/site-recovery/#overview

discussion.content: Answer is B. Azure Site Recovery. Site Recovery has a RTO SLA of 2 hours. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/site-recovery/azure-to-azure-common-questions Site Recovery creates a crash-consistent recovery point every 5 minutes. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/site-recovery/azure-to-azure-common-questions

Because data is replicated to the secondary region asynchronously, a failure that affects the primary region may result in data loss if the primary region cannot be recovered. The interval between the most recent writes to the primary region and the last write to the secondary region is known as the recovery point objective (RPO). The RPO indicates the point in time to which data can be recovered. Azure Storage typically has an RPO of less than 15 minutes, although there's currently no SLA on how long it takes to replicate data to the secondary region.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/common/storage-redundancy
NOTE: You need to recommend a business continuity solution for the payroll system... Answer is B. Azure Site Recovery

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/common/storage-redundancy
Storage accounts that contain Azure managed disks for virtual machines always use LRS. Azure unmanaged disks should also use LRS. It is possible to create a storage account for Azure unmanaged disks that uses GRS, but it is not recommended due to potential issues with consistency over asynchronous geo-replication. Neither managed nor unmanaged disks support ZRS or GZRS.
Answer is B. Azure Site Recovery

B.
Site recovery RPO is 5 min.

Azure Storage typically has an RPO of less than 15 minutes, although there's currently no SLA on how long it takes to replicate data to the secondary region.
Site Recovery creates a crash-consistent recovery point every 5 minutes. You can't change this frequency which achieves the required RPO

questions.question_text:
The accounting department at your company migrates to a new financial accounting software. The accounting department must keep file-based database backups for seven years for compliance purposes. It is unlikely that the backups will be used to recover data.
You need to move the backups to Azure. The solution must minimize costs.
Where should you store the backups?

choices.D: Azure Blob storage that uses the Cool tier
choices.B: Azure Blob storage that uses the Archive tier

comments.content: B is ok

discussion.content: B is correct…Blob Solution with Archive tier is the cheapest cost.
B ..The data is unlikely to be recovered and hence goes for Archive storage.
Yes it is correct answer
B. Azure Blob storage that uses the Archive tier
B is correct answer.
B is correct

B is correct!
